sentences: Hikaru Utada (宇多田 ヒカル, Utada Hikaru, born January 19, 1983), who is also known by the mononym Utada, is a Japanese-American singer-songwriter and producer.
section: N/A

sentences: Born in the United States to Japanese parents, record producer Teruzane Utada and enka singer Keiko Fuji, Utada began to write music and lyrics at an early age and often traveled to Tokyo as a result of her father's job.
section: N/A

sentences: Eventually, a recording contract with Toshiba-EMI was signed.
section: N/A

sentences: Under the stage name Cubic U, she released an English-language debut album Precious in early 1998, but it was a commercial failure.
section: N/A

sentences: In the following year, heavily influenced by R&B and dance-pop, a Japanese-language debut First Love was released and became an immediate success.
section: N/A

sentences: Backed by the success of singles "Automatic", "Time Will Tell", and "Movin' On Without You", the album sold two million copies in its first week in Japan, topped the Oricon charts for six non-consecutive weeks and went on to sell six million more throughout the rest of 1999.
section: N/A

sentences: First Love eventually became the country's best-selling album of all time.
section: N/A

sentences: The following album, Distance, was released in early 2001 and spawned Utada's biggest hit singles—"Addicted to You", "Wait & See (Risk)" and "Can You Keep a Secret?"—which became million-sellers.
section: N/A

sentences: The album was commercially successful and broke several sales records after three million copies were sold in its first week of availability in Japan, instantly becoming the country's fastest-selling album.
section: N/A

sentences: In 2002, backed by chart-topping singles such as "Traveling", "Hikari" and "Sakura Drops", Deep River, which incorporates elements of pop folk, was released and went on to become one of Japan's top-selling records of all-time.
section: N/A

sentences: Subsequent full-length releases—Exodus, Ultra Blue and Heart Station—achieved million-selling status certified by the Recording Industry Association of Japan.
section: N/A

sentences: After a prolonged hiatus, she released the acoustic-driven albums Fantôme and Hatsukoi, which reached number one on the Oricon album charts.
section: N/A

sentences: By the end of the 2000s, Utada was deemed "the most influential artist of the decade" in the Japanese music landscape by The Japan Times.
section: N/A

sentences: Commercial success has made her one of Japan's top-selling recording artists of all time with over 50 million records sold since launching her career in the late 1990s.
section: N/A

sentences: Twelve of her singles have reached number one on the Oricon Singles Chart, while ten albums have become chart-toppers.

sentences: Six of her full-length releases are among the country's highest-selling albums of all time, including First Love, Distance and Deep River, which are among the top ten best-selling records of Japan's music history.

== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Utada is bilingual and speaks English and Japanese fluently.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On September 7, 2002, she married Kazuaki Kiriya, a photographer and film director who had directed several of her music videos.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: He was fifteen years her senior.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On March 2, 2007, the couple announced their divorce, citing personal changes and lack of communication due to the nature of their jobs.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On August 22, 2013, Utada's mother, Keiko Fuji, died by apparent suicide by jumping from the thirteenth floor of a 28-floor condominium building in Shinjuku, Tokyo.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On February 3, 2014, Utada announced plans to be wedded to an Italian man, asking for fans and the media to view their personal lives from a "respectable distance" as he was not in the entertainment industry.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On the same day, ex-husband Kazuaki Kiriya congratulated her on the new marriage.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On February 10, 2014, Utada and fiancé Francesco Calianno left a message on her official website explaining how they met each other while Calianno was a bartender in a London hotel, and asking for privacy.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: The couple were married on May 23, 2014.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On July 3, 2015, the couple announced the birth of a son.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On April 6, 2018, it was announced that they had divorced.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On June 26, 2021, Utada came out as non-binary in an Instagram livestream.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Utada uses she/her and they/them pronouns.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Utada has supported same-sex marriage and, in discussing discomfort with how titles like Ms. or Mrs. closely identify someone by sex and marital status, supported widespread use of the gender-neutral title Mx.
section: == Personal life ==
== Musical style ==

sentences: Musical style ==
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Utada is a core component of the ever-changing J-pop music genre, bringing her American-inflected R&B vocal style to a mix of soulful ballads, bouncy dance-pop, and standard pop songs.
section: == Musical style ==

sentences: Influences ===

sentences: Utada's official website cites 16 musicians and composers as her favorite artists: Freddie Mercury, Cocteau Twins, Nine Inch Nails, Jimi Hendrix, Prince, Amel Larrieux, Édith Piaf, Chick Corea, the Blue Nile, Björk, Kate Bush, Akino Arai, Lenny Kravitz, Béla Bartók, Mozart, Jeff Buckley, Yutaka Ozaki, and Hibari Misora.
section: == Musical style == | === Influences ===

sentences: Elsewhere, she has also listed R&B artists Aaliyah, Mariah Carey, and Mary J. Blige as inspirations, and has previously mentioned growing up as a fan of Madonna, Sting, and the Cure.
